questions.text: A 10-year-old male presents with acute onset of severe itching, lacrimation, photophobia, and watering. On examination, moderate chemosis was also noted. His mother reported that he has had recurrent attacks of such episodes. On examination, the following findings were noticed. What is the diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Vernal keratoconjunctivitis. Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a recurrent bilateral disorder in which both IgE- and cell-mediated immune mechanisms play important roles. It primarily affects boys and onset is generally from about the age of 5 years onwards. Symptoms consist of intense itching, which may be associated with lacrimation, photophobia, a foreign body sensation, burning, and thick mucoid discharge. Increased blinking is common. Macro papillae (<1 mm) have a flat-topped polygonal appearance reminiscent of cobblestones ; as seen in the Image given. Focal or diffuse whitish inflammatory infiltrates may be seen in intense disease.

Highyeild:

Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or SPRING CATARRH It is allergic keratoconjunctivitis, self-limiting, allergic inflammation It is a Type I hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgE and mast cells. Pathological changes lead to the formation of papillae in the upper tarsal conjunctiva. It is also called spring catarrh. symptoms: Marked burning and itching sensation Mild photophobia, lacrimation, stringy (ropy) discharge Signs: Cobblestone appearance Horner Trantas spots Superficial punctate keratitis Shield ulcer Pseudogerontoxon Keratoconus Treatment: Topical anti-inflammatory therapy Topical lubricating and mucolytics Antihistaminics Steroids for a short duration Topical cyclosporine (0.5 to 1%)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Perennial allergic conjunctivitis causes symptoms throughout the year , generally worse in the autumn when exposure to house dust mites , animal dander, and fungal allergens is greatest. It is less common and tends to be milder than the seasonal form. Option: B. Seasonal allergic conjunctivitis (‘hay fever eyes’), usually occurs or worsens during the spring and summer It is the more common subtype of allergic conjunctivitis. The most frequent allergens are tree and grass pollen, although the specific allergen varies with geographic location. It is typically seen in younger children after playing outside in spring or summer. Acute itching and watering are common, but the hallmark is chemosis, which is frequently dramatic and worrying to the child and parents. Option: D. Atopic keratoconjunctivitis (AKC) is rare bilateral disease that typically develops in adulthood (peak incidence 30–50 years) following a long history of atopic dermatitis (eczema). Asthma is also extremely common in these patients . About 5% have suffered from childhood VKC. AKC tends to be chronic and unremitting, with a relatively low expectation of eventual resolution and is associated with significant visual morbidity. Whereas VKC is more frequently seasonal and generally worse in the spring, AKC tends to be perennial and is often worse in the winter. Symptoms are similar to those of VKC but are frequently more severe and unremitting.

Extraedge:

ALLERGIC CONJUNCTIVITIS It is the inflammation of the conjunctiva due to allergic or hypersensitivity reactions which may be immediate (humeral) or delayed (cellular). The conjunctiva is ten times more sensitive than the skin to allergens. Types: Simple allergic conjunctivitis Seasonal allergic conjunctivitis (SAC) Perennial allergic conjunctivitis (PAC) Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) Atopic keratoconjunctivitis (J\KC) Giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC) Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis (PKC) Dermatoconjunctivitis (ADC)

His mother reported that he has had recurrent attacks of such episodes. On examination, a cobblestone pattern of papillae was noticed. Which of the following statements are not true about this patient’s condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Pseudo gerontoxon is not a common feature

options.label: D
options.text: Vascularization does not tend to be prominent

questions.correct_answer: C. Pseudo gerontoxon is not a common feature
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pseudo gerontoxon is not a common feature The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Vernal keratoconjunctivitis. Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a recurrent bilateral disorder in which both IgE- and cell-mediated immune mechanisms play important roles. It primarily affects boys and onset is generally from about the age of 5 years onwards. Symptoms consist of intense itching, which may be associated with lacrimation, photophobia, a foreign body sensation, burning, and thick mucoid discharge. Increased blinking is common.

Highyeild:

Pseudo gerontoxon can develop in recurrent limbal disease. It is characterized by a para limbal band of superficial scarring resembling arcus senilis, adjacent to a previously inflamed segment of the limbus.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Epithelial macro erosions caused by a combination of epithelial toxicity from inflammatory mediators and a direct mechanical effect from papillae. Option: B. Plaques and ‘shield’ ulcers may develop in palpebral or mixed disease when the exposed Bowman membrane becomes coated with mucus and calcium phosphate, leading to inadequate wetting and delayed re-epithelialization. This development is serious and warrants urgent attention to prevent secondary bacterial infection. Option: D. Vascularization does not tend to be prominent, though some peripheral superficial vessel ingrowth is common, especially superior.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female is suffering from redness of the conjunctiva and surrounding skin with fissuring of eyelids. She reported that this happened after she started using makeup on her eyes. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contact allergic blepharoconjunctivitis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Contact allergic blepharoconjunctivitis. Analogous to contact dermatitis, this refers to the acute or subacute T-cell-mediated delayed hypersensitivity reaction seen most commonly by ophthalmologists as a reaction to eye drop constituents and by optometrists as a reaction to contact lens solutions. Mascara is a less common cause. There may be a conjunctival reaction, but signs predominantly involve the eyelid skin: erythema, thickening, induration and sometimes fissuring occur.

Highyeild:

Blepharoconjunctivitis can be caused by a variety of issues and is often multifactoria In the acute form, it is useful to categorize the causes by clinical features. If the onset is acute with ulcerating features , this points to an infective process, with the most common organism being Staphylococcus . However, if the onset is acute with no ulceration, this points to an allergic process . If the onset is chronic, one can categorize the causes via the anatomy involved – posterior versus angular versus anterior . Meibomian gland dysfunction is often the culprit in blepharoconjunctivitis involving the posterior aspect of the eyelid. If there is the involvement of the canthal angle, this is angular blepharoconjunctivitis and can be caused by an infection such as Moraxella or, in rare cases, deficiency of vitamin B6. If the anterior eyelid is involved, this can point to an infection such as Staphylococcus or a seborrheic process . There is an association between this and acne rosacea.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Atopic keratoconjunctivitis (AKC) is rare bilateral disease that typically develops in adulthood (peak incidence 30–50 years ) following a long history of atopic dermatitis (eczema). Asthma is also extremely common in these patients. Option C: Mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis, the severe form of which is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC), can occur secondary to a variety of mechanical stimuli of the tarsal conjunctiva. It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear when it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). The risk is increased by the build-up of proteinaceous deposits and cellular debris on the CL surface. Option D: Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a recurrent bilateral disorder in which both IgE- and cell-mediated immune mechanisms play important roles. It primarily affects boys and onset is generally from about the age of 5 years onwards . Symptoms consist of intense itching, which may be associated with lacrimation, photophobia, a foreign body sensation, burning, and thick mucoid discharge. Increased blinking is common. Other causes of blepharoconjunctivitis include parasitic infections such as Demodex , pubic lice, and drugs such as dupilumab.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female came in with dry eyes, itchiness, and watering. On exam, you notice the shortening of the inferior fornices and the below findings. Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding the patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The condition involves a cell-mediated delayed hypersensitivity reaction, usually related to drug exposure

options.label: B
options.text: Typically presents in old age and affects females more commonly

options.label: D
options.text: Ankyloblepharon may occur in these patients

questions.correct_answer: A. The condition involves a cell-mediated delayed hypersensitivity reaction, usually related to drug exposure
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The condition involves a cell-mediated delayed hypersensitivity reaction, usually related to drug exposure The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Mucous membrane pemphigoid (MMP), also known as ocular cicatricial pemphigoid (OCP). The Images show symblepharon formation and severe skin blistering. Symblepharon formation refers to adhesion between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva and is seen in this disease. Mucous membrane pemphigoid (MMP), also known as ocular cicatricial pemphigoid (OCP), comprises a group of chronic autoimmune mucocutaneous blistering diseases. There is a loss of hemidesmosomes attachment of the epithelium to the basement membrane.

Highyeild:

Ocular cicatricial pemphigoid (OCP) Ocular cicatricial pemphigoid Previously sometimes referred to as benign mucous membrane pemphigoid , this is a rare but very serious disease of unknown origin affecting both eyes . It generally affects those older than 50 years and is of insidious onset with remissions and exacerbations. There is a loss of hemidesmosomes attachment of the epithelium to the basement membrane. Symptoms: include foreign body sensation, redness, watering, and photophobia. Signs: Vesicles occur on the conjunctiva, but more commonly greyish-white membranous patches are seen . Progressive cicatrization follows, eventually leading to essential shrinkage of the conjunctiva, formation of inferior symblepharon, shallowing of the inferior fornix, severe dry eye, superficial punctate keratopathy, entropion, trichiasis, pannus, keratinization and consequent opacification of the cornea . Similar lesions may be found in the nose, mouth, palate, pharynx, esophagus, anus, vagina, urethra, and, more rarely, on the skin. Investigations : The diagnosis is made by conjunctival biopsy for immunofluorescence staining and dermatological, otorhinolaryngological, and gastrointestinal specialist consultations. Management: Depending on the severity of involvement, treatment with artificial tears, protective moisture-retaining glasses, punctal occlusion,topical and systemic steroids, dapsone, immunosuppressive therapy, surgery by mucous membrane grafts and keratoprosthesis for end-stage corneal disease. Local treatment, such as transplantation of the mucous membrane, is disappointing as is general treatment. Hydrophilic contact lenses together with artificial tears may be helpful.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Mucous membrane pemphigoid (MMP) typically presents in old age and affects females more commonly than males by a 2: 1 ratio. Option: C. Diagnosis is principally clinical, but biopsy of the involved mucous membrane often shows supportive changes (linear antibody and complement BMZ deposition) . Progression has been divided into stages as follows: Option: D. Ankyloblepharon is an adhesion at the outer canthus between the upper and lower lids. It is a common feature of eyelid involvement in ocular cicatricial pemphigoid.

Extraedge:

Foster’s classification system : Stage I: early stage associated with chronic conjunctivitis, tear dysfunction, and subepithelial fibrosis. Stage II: fornical shortening, particularly inferiorly. Stage III: symblepharon formation. Stage IV: surface keratinization and cicatricial ankyloblepharon.

questions.text: Match the ocular findings given in the Images below to the disease processes they are most characteristically seen in. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a Image 1: Symblepharon formation is shown in the Image. Symblepharon formation refers to adhesion between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva and is seen in ocular cicatricial pemphigoid. Image 2: Severe eyelid involvement due to atopic disease is seen in the Image. Skin changes are more prominent than in VKC and are typically eczematoid: erythema, dryness, scaling, and thickening, sometimes with disruption to epidermal integrity such as fissuring and scratches (excoriation), the latter due to intense itching. Image 3: Giant papillae can be seen in this Image with inflammatory infiltrates. This is a characteristic feature of Palpebral vernal keratoconjunctivitis. Image 4: Limbal papillae are seen with Horner-Trantas dots. Gelatinous limbal conjunctival papillae that may be associated with transient apically located white cellular collections are characteristically seen in limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

Highyeild:

VKC Signs: Two typical forms are seen: (i) the palpebral form and (ii) the limbal or bulbar form. The palpebral form is easily recognized. On everting the upper lid, the palpebral conjunctiva is seen to be hypertrophied and mapped out into polygonal raised areas, not unlike cobblestones . The color is bluish-white , like milk, and this appearance may also be seen over the lower palpebral conjunctiva. The flat-topped nodules are hard and consist chiefly of dense fibrous tissue , but the epithelium over them is thickened, giving rise to the milky hue. Histologically, they are hypertrophied papillae, not follicles . Eosinophilic Leukocytes are present in them in great numbers and are found in secretion. In addition, infiltration with lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages, basophils, and eosinophils may be seen.

Extraedge:

The limbal or bulbar form is recognized by opacification of the limbus , with nodules or a wall of gelatinous thickening at the limbus . White dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris, known as Horner–Trantas dots, if seen at the limbus are a very characteristic feature.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was referred to the ophthalmology department due to the following findings. He is an HIV-positive patient with newly started chemotherapy. The doctor in charge reported that he also had an onset of malaise, nasal discharge, and pain on eating and drinking along with these findings. Which of the following steps of management are not adequate for this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dapsone The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Steven Johnson syndrome. Haemorrhagic lid crusting is seen in the 1st Image. Corneal keratinization is seen in the 2nd Image . Both these findings are characteristic of cicatricial involvement caused due to SJS. The patient has recently been started on a chemotherapy regimen for HIV which serves as a trigger for SJS. A wide range of medications have been incriminated, including antibiotics (especially sulfonamides and trimethoprim), analgesics including paracetamol (acetaminophen), nevirapine (widely prescribed as a part of combination therapy for HIV infection), cold remedies, and anticonvulsants. Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN – Lyell syndrome) is a severe variant of SJS. SJS/TEN patients tend to be young adults, though other groups may be affected. The condition involves a cell-mediated delayed hypersensitivity reaction, usually related to drug exposure Dapsone is NOT indicated in the management of Steven Johnson syndrome.

Highyeild:

Management of SJS : Ocular treatment in the acute stage includes supportive therapy with topical lubricants , antibiotics to prevent secondary bacterial infection, and lysis of adhesions formed between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva by passing a glass rod coated with antibiotic or plain paraffin ointment in the fornices. The late cicatricial stage can be treated medically to control the manifestations of a dry eye and lid deformities can be surgically

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Scleral ring is used to prevent symblepharon formation in Stevens–Johnson syndrome Option: B. Adequate lubrication should be done, including punctal occlusion if required. Option: C. Corneal rehabilitation may involve superficial keratectomy for keratinization, lamellar corneal grafting for superficial scarring (preferred to penetrating keratoplasty), amniotic membrane grafting, limbal stem cell transplantation and keratoprosthesis implantation in end-stage disease.

Extraedge:

Additional measures such as punctal occlusion , transplantation of conjunctival or buccal mucous membrane, and transplantation of limbal stem cells with amniotic membrane to promote healing may be needed to restore the integrity of the damaged ocular surface.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with mucoid discharge, itchiness and foreign body sensation. On examination you notice frequent blinking, mild superior pannus and below findings. Past medical history is significant for hyperthyroidism, well controlled with medications. Which of the following statements are not true about the patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The condition is believed to be the result of blink-related trauma between the upper lid and the superior bulbar conjunctiva

options.label: B
options.text: This condition is analogous to Conjunctivochalasis

options.label: C
options.text: Enquiry should be made about CL wear and previous eyelid surgery or trauma

options.label: D
options.text: It is a recurrent bilateral disorder in which both IgE- and cell-mediated immune mechanisms play important roles

questions.correct_answer: D. It is a recurrent bilateral disorder in which both IgE- and cell-mediated immune mechanisms play important roles
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a recurrent bilateral disorder in which both IgE- and cell-mediated immune mechanisms play important roles The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis. Image 1 shows hyperaemic band of superior bulbar conjunctiva with limbal papillae (arrow); Image 2 shows diffuse velvety papillary hypertrophy Superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis (SLK) is a relatively uncommon chronic disease of the superior limbus and the superior bulbar and tarsal conjunctiva. It affects one or both eyes of middle-aged women, approximately 50% of whom have abnormal thyroid function (usually hyperthyroidism). With increased conjunctival movement there is mechanical damage to the tarsal and bulbar conjunctival surfaces, the resultant inflammatory response leading to increasing conjunctival oedema and redundancy, with the creation of a self-perpetuating cycle.

Highyeild:

Papillary hypertrophy of the superior tarsal plate, often having a diffuse velvety appearance is a characteristic feature.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The condition is believed to be the result of blink-related trauma between the upper lid and the superior bulbar conjunctiva, precipitated in many cases by tear film insufficiency and an excess of lax conjunctival tissue. With increased conjunctival movement there is mechanical damage to the tarsal and bulbar conjunctival surfaces, the resultant inflammatory response leading to increasing conjunctival oedema and redundancy, with the creation of a self-perpetuating cycle. Option: B. Conjunctivochalasis is characterized by one or more folds of redundant conjunctiva prolapsing over the lower eyelid margin. It can exacerbate the symptoms of dry eye and commonly contributes to epiphora, of which it can be an under-recognized cause. It is thought to be predominantly an involutional process involving the loss of conjunctival adhesion to the underlying Tenon capsule and episclera and may be analogous to the conjunctival abnormalities leading to superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis. Option: C. There are similarities to mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis and a comparable clinical picture has been described with contact lens wear and following upper lid surgery or trauma. Enquiry should be made about CL wear and previous eyelid surgery or trauma.

Extraedge:

Superior punctate corneal epithelial erosions are common and are often separated from the limbus by a zone of normal epithelium.

questions.text: A 1-year-old female presents with pseudomembranous lesions on the conjunctiva. Exam findings are shown in the Image below. Which of the following statements are not correct about this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Histopathology shows amorphous subepithelial deposits of eosinophilic material

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical removal is necessary for adequate resolution

options.label: D
options.text: Episodes may be triggered by relatively minor trauma, or by systemic events

questions.correct_answer: B. Presentation is usually in adulthood
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Presentation is usually in adulthood The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Ligneous conjunctivitis Image shows gradually enlarging red–white lobular conjunctival masses , which are typical ligneous masses. Ligneous conjunctivitis is a very rare potentially sight- and even life-threatening disorder characterized by recurrent, often bilateral fibrin-rich pseudomembranous lesions of wood-like consistency that develop mainly on the tarsal conjunctiva .

Highyeild:

It is generally a systemic condition and may involve the periodontal tissue, the upper and lower respiratory tract, kidneys, middle ear, and female genitalia. Presentation is with nonspecific conjunctivitis, usually in childhood (median age 5 years), although onset may be at any age. A conjunctival lesion is commonly noted by parents.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Histopathology shows amorphous subepithelial deposits of eosinophilic material consisting predominantly of fibrin Option: C. Surgical removal with meticulous diathermy of the base of the lesion is necessary for adequate resolution. Preoperative topical plasminogen may soften pseudomembranes and facilitate removal. Option: D. A deficiency in plasmin-mediated fibrinolysis may be a key common factor in many patients. Episodes may be triggered by relatively minor trauma, or by systemic events such as fever and antifibrinolytic therapy.

Extraedge:

Signs include: Gradually enlarging red –white lobular conjunctival masses which may be covered by a thick yellow–white mucoid discharge. Corneal scarring, vascularization, infection, or melting .

questions.text: A 2-year-old female was rushed to the hospital after she was suddenly found to be extremely irritable and having crying fits due to itchiness of eyes and profuse watering. The parents reported that this episode started after their daughter was left alone in the bathtub for a few minutes. On examination you notice the following findings after checking with Rose Bengal stain. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Factitious keratoconjunctivitis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of factitious keratoconjunctivitis. Inferior conjunctival injection and staining with rose Bengal in factitious conjunctivitis is seen in the given Image. The history of this pediatric patient left alone in the bathtub followed by classic symptoms leads to the diagnosis of factitious keratoconjunctivitis. Self-injury (factitious keratoconjunctivitis) is most often intentional , but can also occur inadvertently, as in mucus fishing syndrome and removal of contact lenses. Damage may be the result of either mechanical trauma or of the instillation of an irritant but readily accessible household substances, such as soap.

Highyeild:

Signs may include: Inferior conjunctival injection and staining with rose Bengal as seen in the Image with quiet superior bulbar conjunctiva. Linear corneal abrasions, persistent epithelial defects, and occasionally focal corneal perforation. Corneal scarring.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Atopic keratoconjunctivitis (AKC) is rare bilateral disease that typically develops in adulthood ( ak incidence 30–50 years) following a long history of atopic dermatitis (eczema). Asthma is also extremely common in these patients. There is little or no gender preponderance. AKC tends to be chronic and unremitting, with a relatively low expectation of eventual resolution and is associated with significant visual morbidity. Option: B. Parinaud oculoglandular syndrome is a rare condition consisting of chronic low-grade fever, unilateral granulomatous conjunctivitis as seen in the figure with surrounding follicles, and ipsilateral regional (preauricular) lymphadenopathy . It is synonymous with cat scratch disease, although several other causes have been implicated, including tularaemia, insect hairs (ophthalmia nodosa), Treponema Pallidum, sporotrichosis, tuberculosis, and acute C. trachomatis infection. Option: D. Ligneous conjunctivitis is a very rare potentially sight- and even life-threatening disorder characterized by recurrent, often bilateral fibrin-rich pseudomembranous lesions of wood-like consistency that develop mainly on the tarsal conjunctiva. It is generally a systemic condition and may involve the periodontal tissue, the upper and lower respiratory tract, kidneys, the middle ear, and female genitalia. Presentation is with nonspecific conjunctivitis, usually in childhood (median age 5 years), although onset may be at any age.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient recently underwent an allogeneic hematological stem cell transplant. He came in for a follow-up and reported that he has been suffering from extreme dryness of the eyes, itchiness, foreign body sensation, blurring of vision, and redness. On exam, you notice corneal erosion, thinning, and cicatricial changes in the conjunctiva. What is your initial impression?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ocular graft-versus-host disease The given case history and findings point toward the diagnosis of Ocular graft-versus-host disease. Ocular graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) occurs in patients who have undergone allogeneic hematological stem cell transplantation. It can occur in patients who have acute or chronic GVHD, although it is more frequently seen in the chronic form.

Highyeild:

Clinically it manifests in a similar fashion to Stevens–Johnson syndrome. Ocular manifestations develop in 40–60% of patients after stem cell transplantation and can lead to significant ocular surface consequences.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN – Lyell syndrome) is a severe variant of SJS. SJS/TEN patients tend to be young adults, though other groups may be affected. The condition involves a cell-mediated delayed hypersensitivity reaction , usually related to drug exposure. A wide range of medications have been incriminated, including antibiotics (especially sulfonamides and trimethoprim), analgesics including paracetamol (acetaminophen), nevirapine (widely prescribed as a part of combination therapy for HIV infection), cold remedies, and anticonvulsants. Option: B. Parinaud oculoglandular syndrome is a rare condition consisting of chronic low-grade fever, unilateral granulomatous conjunctivitis as seen in the figure with surrounding follicles, and ipsilateral regional (preauricular) lymphadenopathy. It is synonymous with cat scratch disease, although several other causes have been implicated, including tularaemia, insect hairs (ophthalmia nodosum), Treponema Pallidum, sporotrichosis, tuberculosis, and acute C. trachomatis infection. Option: C. Conjunctivochalasis is characterized by one or more folds of redundant conjunctiva prolapsing over the lower eyelid margin. It can exacerbate the symptoms of dry eye and commonly contributes to epiphora, of which it can be an under-recognized cause. It is thought to be predominantly an involutional process involving the loss of conjunctival adhesion to the underlying Tenon capsule and episclera and may be analogous to the conjunctival abnormalities leading to superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis.

Extraedge:

Ocular features Dry eye syndrome (keratoconjunctivitis sicca). Conjunctival hyperemia with pseudomembrane and membrane formation. Chronic inflammation leads to cicatricial changes in the conjunctiva and occasionally entropion formation. Corneal manifestations include punctate epithelial keratopathy , marginal keratitis, and filamentary keratitis. Severe disease can lead to corneal erosion, thinning, ulceration, and possible perforation .

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with severe conjunctival scarring, cough, and blisters on the skin. The exam findings are displayed in the Images below. He reported the presence of flu-like symptoms a week ago which resolved after taking unrecalled medications. Past medical history is significant for epilepsy, for which the patient was started on anticonvulsants 3 weeks ago. The patient has long-standing diabetes as well as asthma and is well-compliant with medications. Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding the patient’s condition

options.label: A
options.text: Healing of skin manifestations usually occurs within 1–4 weeks in mild-moderate cases

options.label: B
options.text: Widespread sloughing of the epidermis is common

options.label: D
options.text: Scleral ring should be used for management

questions.correct_answer: B. Widespread sloughing of the epidermis is common
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Widespread sloughing of the epidermis is common The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Steven Johnson syndrome . The Images show hemorrhagic lid crusting, corneal keratinization, and hemorrhagic lip crusting. Here the patient was recently started on anticonvulsants which are a known trigger for this condition. Patient’s symptoms were preceded by a flu-like episode; followed by characteristic systemic manifestations. Widespread sloughing of the epidermis is uncommon in Steven Johnson Syndrome. Mucosal involvement is characterized by blistering and hemorrhagic crusting of the lips . The blisters may also involve the tongue, oropharynx, nasal mucosa, and occasionally the genitalia. Small purpuric, vesicular, hemorrhagic, or necrotic skin lesions involving the extremities, face, and trunk may also occur. These are usually transient but may be widespread.

Highyeild:

Stevens–johnson syndrome (erythema multiforme major) This is a type II hypersensitivity reaction usually due to an immunological reaction to drugs (sulphonamides, NSAIDs, antibiotics, antimalarials, antiepileptics such as barbiturates and phenytoin ) or systemic infections(caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, herpes simplex virus, and some fungi ). It is a serious disease, which is fatal in some patients, and characterized by skin rash, erythematous lesions, followed by bullae and epidermal necrosis, fever, malaise, and ulcerative lesions of the mucous membranes, particularly the mouth and th35-year-old ocular sequelae include severe dry eye, symblepharon, lid deformity (cicatricial entropion), corneal vascularization, and scarring .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Healing of skin manifestations usually occurs within 1–4 weeks, leaving a pigmented scar. Option: C. Keratopathy including scarring, vascularization, and keratinization as seen in Image 2 occurs as a result of the primary inflammation and/or infection, as well as cicatricial entropion and aberrant lashes. Option: D. Scleral ring should be used to prevent symblepharon formation in Stevens–Johnson syndrome

Extraedge:

Ocular treatment in the acute stage includes supportive therapy with topical lubricants, antibiotics to prevent secondary bacterial infection and lysis of adhesions formed between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva by passing a glass rod coated with antibiotic or plain paraffin ointment in the fornices. The late cicatricial stage can be treated medically to control the manifestations of a dry eye and lid deformities can be surgically corrected. Additional measures such as punctal occlusion, transplantation of conjunctival or buccal mucous membrane, and transplantation of limbal stem cells with amniotic membrane to promote healing may be needed to restore the integrity of the damaged ocular surface.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came in with scaling of eyelids, watery discharge, hyperemia, and intense itching. On exam, you noticed the following findings. What is not true about the patient’s condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Retinal detachment is more common than in the general population

options.label: D
options.text: Dapsone is a useful first-line treatment in patients with mild–moderate disease

questions.correct_answer: D. Dapsone is a useful first-line treatment in patients with mild–moderate disease
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dapsone is a useful first-line treatment in patients with mild–moderate disease The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Atopic keratoconjunctivitis (AKC). The Images sho w intense corneal vascularization and keratinization of the caruncle respectively. Dapsone has no role in the treatment of this disease.

Highyeild:

Atopic keratoconjunctivitis It is generally seen in young adults and often associated with a history of other atopic diseases such as asthma, allergic rhinitis, or atopic eczematous dermatitis in the patient or his/her family. It is responsible for an extremely severe and chronic form of the ocular surface disorder , though the disease spectrum varies in the range of severity from mild to chronic persistent inflammation . It is similar in nature to VKC except that it tends to be more severe, and chronic and extends into adulthood.

questions.text: A 35 year old male recently started wearing contact lenses and presented shortly with giant papillae, mucous discharge, and tarsal hyperemia. Which of these statements is true about the patient’s condition? Contact lens wear should be discontinued for several weeks Antimetabolites are alternatives for mild–moderate disease Keratopathy is rare Skin biopsy may help to establish the diagnosis Select the correct answer from the given below code:

options.label: D
options.text: a, b, c and d only

questions.explanation:
Solution:

a and c only Mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis, the severe form of which is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC), can occur secondary to a variety of mechanical stimuli of the tarsal conjunctiva. It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear when it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). The risk is increased by the build-up of proteinaceous deposits and cellular debris on the CL surface.

Highyeild:

Giant papillary conjunctivitis This is a specific type of allergic inflammation affecting the superior tarsal conjunctiva. Aetiology : It usually occurs due to soft hydrophilic contact lens use, protruding suture ends,s or ocular prostheses. It can also occur rarely after many years of rigid contact lens use. The underlying mechanism is a hypersensitivity reaction (types I and IV) . Symptoms : The usual symptoms are itching, watering, foreign body sensation and, occasionally, blurring of vision. Signs : Signs include conjunctival congestion, which is predominantly in the upper palpebral region with large polygonal papillae on the superior tarsal conjunctiva. Macropapillae are 0.3–1.0 mm in size, and giant papillae are 1–2 mm in size.

Extraedge:

Management: Treatment consists of discontinuing the use of soft contact lenses, removal of offending sutures, cleaning, and polishing of any ocular prosthesis, and replacing it with one coated with a biocompatible material such as Biocoat. Useful ancillary therapy includes mast cell stabilizers (lodoxamide 6 hourly, cromolyn sodium 6 hourly, or olopatadine 12 hourly), along with artificial tears, antihistamine drops, and decongestants. Topical steroids can be administered for a short while and a subtarsal injection of long-acting steroids may be needed in severe cases, provided that the patient is not a steroid responder. Contact lens wear should be discontinued for several weeks: Contact lens (CL) wear should be discontinued for several weeks and the current lenses replaced. For mild–moderate disease, this may be adequate for resolution, sometimes in conjunction with reduced wearing time. In severe CLPC a longer interval without lens wear may be needed. Antimetabolites are alternatives for mild–moderate disease: Antimetabolites have no role in this disease. Antimetabolites serve as 2nd line of management for blistering diseases like Mucous membrane pemphigoid (MMP), where first-line treatments have already been exhausted. Keratopathy is rare: Keratopathy is rare because of the relatively subdued secretion of inflammatory cytokines. A skin biopsy may help to establish the diagnosis: Skin Biopsy has no diagnostic role. It is used for diseases like leprosy or Steven-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, severe itching of the eye with ropy discharge in a 10-year-old boy with symptoms aggravating in the summer season is most likely present:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vernal conjunctivitis With vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), as with other allergic or type I hypersensitivity disorders, itching is the most important and most common symptom. Other commonly reported symptoms are photophobia, foreign body sensation, tearing, and blepharospasm. Photophobia due to chronic keratitis is also common. Ocular signs of VKC commonly are seen in the cornea and conjunctiva. In contrast to atopic keratoconjunctivitis (AKC), the eyelid skin usually is not as significantly involved.

Highyeild:

Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or SPRING CATARRH It is an allergic keratoconjunctivitis, self-limiting, allergic inflammation It is a Type I hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgE and mast cells. Pathological changes lead to the formation of papillae in the upper tarsal conjunctiva. It is also called spring catarrh. symptoms: - Marked burning and itching sensation - Mild photophobia, lacrimation, stringy (ropy) discharge Signs: - Cobblestone appearance - Horner Trantas spots - Superficial punctate keratitis - Shield ulcer - Pseudogerontoxon - Keratoconus Treatment: - Topical anti-inflammatory therapy - Topical lubricating and mucolytics - Antihistaminics - Steroids for a short duration - Topical cyclosporine (0.5 to 1%)

questions.text: A malnourished child from a poor socioeconomic status, residing in overcrowded and dirty areas presents with a nodule around the limbus with hyperemia of surrounding conjunctiva in his left eye. He is also observed to have axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phlyctenular Conjunctivitis Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis is a nodular inflammation of the cornea or conjunctiva that results from a hypersensitivity reaction to a foreign antigen. Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis is postulated to occur secondary to an allergic , hypersensitivity reaction at the cornea or conjunctiva, following re-exposure to an infectious antigen that the host has been previously sensitized to. Antigens of Staphylococcus aureus and Mycobacterium tuberculosis are most commonly associated; however, Herpes simplex, Chlamydia, Streptococcus viridans, Dolosigranulum pigram and intestinal parasites including Hymenolepis nana have also been reported as causative agents.

Highyeild:

Presence of one or more whitish raised nodules on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus, with hyperemia usually of the surrounding conjunctiva, in a child living in bad hygienic conditions (most of the times) are the diagnostic features of phlyctenular conjunctivitis.

Foreign body granulomas initially enlarge in size, but can then remain unchanged for months and sometimes even resolve with no treatment. Option C. Vernal keratoconjunctivitis: Burning eyes. Discomfort in bright light (photophobia). Itchy eyes. The area around the cornea where the white of the eye and the cornea meet (limbus) may become rough and swollen. The inside of the eyelids (most often the upper ones) may become rough and covered with bumps and white mucus. Watering eyes. Option D. Episcleritis: Common symptoms of both forms of episcleritis include Redness. Mild soreness or discomfort. Redness. Light sensitivity.

Extraedge:

Predisposing factors: Age . The peak age group is 3-15 years. Sex . Incidence is higher in girls than boys. Undernourishment . The disease is more common in undernourished children. 4 . Living conditions. Overcrowded and unhygienic. Season. It occurs in all climates but incidence is high in spring and summer seasons.

questions.correct_answer: B. 10% acetylcysteine drops are used for controlling excess mucus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

10% acetylcysteine drops are used for controlling excess mucus The diagnosis is Vernal conjunctivitis. 10% or 20% Acetylcysteine drops 3 to 4 times a day for 1 -2 weeks are useful in controlling excess mucus.

Highyeild:

Treatment of VKC: This is purely symptomatic. Topical therapy : Eye Drops containing antihistamines, mast cell stabilizers, decongestants, preservative-free lubricants, anti-inflammatory agents such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents, mild surface-acting steroids and topical cyclosporine are useful to control the allergic reaction and consequent inflammation. Acetylcysteine, as 10% or 20% drops three to four times a day for 1–2 weeks, is useful in controlling excess mucus . Medications are prescribed in a step ladder approach using minimum medications to start with and adding more depending on the response. Treatment is titrated to the response and tapered off to a maintenance dose. Local therapy : Subtarsal injections of long-acting steroids such as triamcinolone may be required for severe refractory cases. Cryotherapy to the tarsal conjunctiva is sometimes needed to control giant papillae. Surgical treatment : Surgical excision of giant papillae may be required. Shield ulcers can be treated with debridement of the surface and the application of an amniotic membrane and/or a bandage contact lens to promote healing. Systemic therapy : Oral antiallergic medications can be used for a short while in severe bilateral cases with severe symptoms, especially itching, not easily relieved with topical treatment. Chronic cases with secondary mucin-deficient dry eyes can be benefitted from oral treatment with nutritional supplements containing omega-3 fatty acids. Supportive therapy : Cold compresses and tinted glasses are helpful and provide considerable comfort.
